subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: ... Yes, but only for some accents (mine included). I ll restate my earlier conclusion based on focused attention on /yr/ in my own reading and writing: I
messageBody:
On Dec 4, 2007 9:53 AM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> NOTE: I'm using ThothSampa for my notation
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> >
> > Well, QS has letters for diphthongs, which are arguably two sounds.
> > Personally I think it's perfectly clear to user #36+25 for NURSE,
> > whether displayed as a ligature or simply two letters quite close
> > together. I don't see why we would need to consider the ligature to be
> > a separate letter.
>
> But we have discussed how y + r can be ambiguous and lead to reading
> problems. In arrest /yrEst/ the y + r sounds completely different from
> the combination in the word "urge" /yrJ/.

Yes, but only for some accents (mine included). I'll restate my
earlier conclusion based on focused attention on /yr/ in my own
reading and writing: I think this is a minor issue that is quickly
overcome with a little practice. Given that many people will not have
this issue at all, I think it does not warrant any change in usage.


> > My dictionary defines a phoneme as "any of the perceptually distinct
> > unit of sound in a specified language that distinguish one word from
> > another". Call me crazy, but I think I can perceive two units of
> > sounds in /3r/.
>
> Yes, I understand. But there is no phoneme for /3/. But in English, /3/
> is only used with the combination of /r/, so it doesn't make sense to
> have a special letter just for /3/, but it does make sense to have one
> letter for the combination of /3r/.
>
>
> >
> > I would be interested to know more about how Read's thinking evolved
> > as he proceeded from Shavian to Quickscript. The fact is, he didn't
> > assign /3r/ to a single letter.
> >
>
> In this particular area, he gives no clue, so far as I know. He wanted
> to simplify the distinction between Noon and /n/, but I think he might
> have went to far.
>
> Paul
>
>
